also, i'm not sure why you need to subtract from the `contextView` frame height. can't you simply check the origin of the `keyboardView` frame?

body: this change should be reverted if possible

1. remove comment
2. cannot refer to "self.property" in `dealloc`

From [Advanced Memory Management Programming Guide]()

> **Don’t Use Accessor Methods in Initializer Methods and dealloc**
> The only places you shouldn’t use accessor methods to set an instance variable are in initializer methods and dealloc.

Because of (2) this should remain `_keyboardView = nil;` and observers should be removed manually.

body:
1. rename `- (void)jsq_addKeyboardFrameObserver`
2. move method definition to be above `- (void)jsq_removeKeyboardFrameObserver`
removal of this `if` should be reverted

this change should be reverted (i.e., leave the try/catch). 

this is the **only** way to safely unsubscribe, as [NSHipster](http://nshipster.com/key-value-observing/) notes:

> Perhaps the most pronounced annoyance with KVO is how it gets you at the end. If you make a call to –`removeObserver:forKeyPath:context:` when the object is not registered as an observer (whether because it was already unregistered or not registered in the first place). The kicker is that _there's no built-in way to even check if an object is registered!_
removal of this `if` should be reverted
~~try / catch should stay, as noted above.~~
we only need one context for this class. revert.
~~revert these changes, keeping single context variable~~
style: `else` on newline, as above.
~~again, keep try / catch, as noted above~~

Because the calls are now evenly balanced, the try/catch is no longer necessary. Try/catch is also not very idiomatic Objective-C, as described in [Exception Programming Topics](https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/documentation/Cocoa/Conceptual/Exceptions/Exceptions.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/10000012-BAJGFBFB):

> Important: You should reserve the use of exceptions for programming or unexpected runtime errors such as out-of-bounds collection access, attempts to mutate immutable objects, sending an invalid message, and losing the connection to the window server. You usually take care of these sorts of errors with exceptions when an application is being created rather than at runtime.

and 

> The Cocoa frameworks are generally not exception-safe. The general pattern is that exceptions are reserved for programmer error only, and the program catching such an exception should quit soon afterwards.

NSHipster (from the same [KVO article](http://nshipster.com/key-value-observing/)) also agrees that catching the exception should be used as a last resort:

> Granted, not handling a caught exception, as in this example, is waving the [UIColor whiteColor] flag of surrender. Therefore, one should only really use this technique when faced with intermittent crashes which cannot be remedied by normal book-keeping (whether due to race conditions or undocumented behavior from a superclass).

Because each KVO observance now has its own context, it's no longer necessary to check the object and the keypath each time the observation method is called. Giving each observance its own context pointer gives us several advantages:
1. It's much easier to read this way
2. It doesn't rely on string comparison
3. It makes it easier to call super in the event that we aren't handling that particular KVO notification

If you're unconvinced, I will revert back to checking all three parameters, but in this case, it is faster, easier to read, and more correct.
Adding a second context here makes the code easier to read. Again, happy to revert, but I hope that you consider it as a good practice.
Fixed
Fixed
Fixed

`jsq_handleKeyboardNotification: completion:` calls this delegate method with a `keyboardFrame` in **contextView** coordinates.

as the docs specify, this method is always passed a `keyboardFrame` in the coordinate system of the context view. these semantics should be preserved.

I know, it took me a lot of time to figure out this, but looks like `UIPeriphalHostView` is rotated when in landscape, when normally the system posts all the `UIKeyboard`notifications always in window coordinates (not rotated). This was the only way around it. 

This is much like using the X coordinate of the `touchInWindow` point when the interface is in landscape ([JSQMessagesKeyboardController.m:332](https://github.com/piercifani/JSQMessagesViewController/blob/fix-opaque-navbar-2/JSQMessagesViewController/Controllers/JSQMessagesKeyboardController.m#L333)).

Anyways, I wanted to find out more about `UIPeripheralHostView` but this was the only piece of code that sets it's frame like this. 

If this feels hacky, it's because it probably is. We could use:

`_scrollView.keyboardDismissMode = UIScrollViewKeyboardDismissModeInteractive;` 

like [RDRStickyKeyboardView](https://github.com/datwelk/RDRStickyKeyboardView) does

Hm. It definitely feels hacky. The problem is, `UIPeriphalHostView` is private API so we shouldn't rely on this.

On rotation, we should receive `UIKeyboardDidChangeFrameNotification`. Can't we utilize that to get the correct frame?

Oh, and I just re-read the comment:

> Here we translate it back to UIWindow coordinates

The problem is, there is no coordinate translation happening on this line.

No, using `UIKeyboardDidChangeFrameNotification` won't help because that notification is only posted when the keyboard is hidden/shown and the rotation changes, but not when we do a `self.keyboardView.frame = someFrame` on the `panGestureRecognizer` callback.

And again, I don't understand why changing Y with X and Width with Height works in there, but it works for now. I think that the best thing is merge this and rewrite keyboard handling to use the new `keyboardDismissMode` for the 6.0 release

 @property (assign, nonatomic) BOOL springinessEnabled;
 
 /**
+ *  Specifies whether or not the layout should use the same width for bubbles in landscape & portrait.
+ *
+ *  @discussion The default value is `NO`, which makes the layout different in portrait vs landscape.
+ *  Set to `YES` if you want chat bubbles to use the portrait width in landscape.
+ *
+ *  When the set to `YES`, there will be a large gap between bubbles down the center.
+ *  However, this has the benefit of making the total scroll height of the layout the same, which means
+ *  that when you rotate from landscape <-> portrait, the same area of the conversation is on screen.
+ *  This is the behavior you can see in the iOS Messages app.
+ *
+ *  When the value it set to `NO` text bubbles change width/height significantly, depending upon bubble-text
+ *  length, resulting in a very different total scroll height, which means that when you rotate
+ *  from landscape <-> portrait, a different portion of the conversation is visible.
+ *
+ *  @warning Though this feature is mostly stable, it is still considered an experimental feature.
+ */
+@property (assign, nonatomic) BOOL rotationIndependentLayout;

body: @jessesquires I guess I can be more verbose in my documentation. Essentially what the loop does is whenever a `UIAlertController` is presented from any context, the app loops through all the view controllers until it gets to the topmost view controller. When I say topmost, I mean the one that's presented. The bug happens because the UIAlertController is trying to present on the rootViewController of the app, but it can't. So this code just keeps going up the "presented tree" until it doesn't find anymore (which means it's at the currently showing view controller), and it presents on that.

body: That was my original plan, but they aren't mix-and-match at this point; you have to configure for one or the other, and the other config method doesn't allow `nil` params. Do you want to allow one or the other set to be nil, but not both?
What if a user wants to just show an avatar image, but no "X is typing…" message, or vice versa?

You'll need to configure this each time you get a 'presence' message saying someone is typing anyway, so I thought I'd leave it up to the consumer to decide what image/message they wanted to show on each config call.

If I'm missing something here please elaborate! I'd love to make it simpler.

Right, so the image and message should change every time, based on who is typing. With this setup, you'd have to repeatedly do `self.typingIndicatorAvatarImage = img;`, etc. 

For each 'presence' message, you'll need to configure the footer view, so that's where this should happen. We should just pass these 2 params to the configure method, no need for properties.

Ah, so I think the design we want here is:
- avatar img
- bubble with ellipsis
- a cellTopLabel saying "xyz is typing"

so avatar and the text could be optional (which would then look like the existing view)

we don't want this hardcoded `5` here.

we should handle this somehow in `controlInsets`
this seems unrelated... ?
maybe we should call this `automaticallyUpdatesSendButtonState` ?

I'm hesitant because setting this property also immediately disables/enables the send button (given there's text in the text view). If the property is called `automaticallyUpdatesSendButtonState` I'd expect the implementation of `updateSendButtonEnabledState` to return early, if this property is set to `NO` instead of it being `AND`ed with `hasText`. But then a user would have to set `automaticallyUpdatesSendButtonState = NO` _and_ manually disable the send button which is two instructions instead of one for the (probably) most common use case "I want to disable the send button, no matter what". 

So maybe `sendButtonDisabled`? The negation here would solve the "setting it to `YES` does not necessarily enable the button"-problem.

Ah, yes: 😊 

Let's have 1 method that accepts a param for the frame, and a convenience method that provides a default.

- `thumbnailFromVideoMediaItem: completion:`
- `thumbnailFromVideoMediaItem: time: completion:`

(The first method should just call the second with a default `time` value)
hey @algrid, is there any issues if you combine inside the `for` loop and use `4` as the terminated number? That's more clear.

we don't need any of this `NSKeyedUnarchiver` stuff.

we should be able to use `- initWithArray:copyItems:` to deep copy.
@algrid I vote for @jessesquires 's solution as I did not know `JSQMessage` has implemented `- copyWithZone:(NSZone *)zone`. `- initWithArray:copyItems:` is more clear.

`- initWithArray:copyItems:` doesn't fix the issue - you can try it in the demo app.  The problem with `- initWithArray:copyItems:` is that it makes only one-level deep copy. But our media view is deeper and it's not copied.

Take a look at this discussion:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/647260/deep-copying-an-nsarray
I've just noticed that I'm calling `archivedDataWithRootObject:` several times for the same data instead of doing it once and saving the result, gonna fix that.

@algrid do you have a screenshot or something? It should be working because `JSQMessage` has implemented `- copyWithZone:(NSZone *)zone` internally. Then, it won't just do a shallow copy. Your way is working but not straightforward.

@Lucashuang0802 The `copyWithZone:` method performs a shallow copy - and that's perfectly ok. Take a look at the 'Discussion' part here: https://developer.apple.com/reference/foundation/nsarray/1408557-initwitharray

Can you reproduce the problem from #1840 in the demo project? If so I can create a version with `- initWithArray:copyItems:` for you to make sure that it's not fixing the bug.

Yes I also was a bit afraid of getting an infinite loop or something like this by invalidating a layout in `-layoutSubviews`. But no problems so far.

I was considering `-setFrame:` but it looks like it isn't a good idea. Take a look here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4000664/is-there-a-uiview-resize-event
, esp. this answer and comments: http://stackoverflow.com/a/23277135

Hey @alattis, I was thinking whether it's actually better to remove this line because the system will call `viewDidLayoutSubviews` when it presents the `JSQMessagesViewController`. It does the same when you call `setNeedsLayout`.
i think this is the only change we need here.
i don't think is this relevant to the fix
i'm almost positive this change is incorrect -- it doesn't account for the keyboard.

`layoutIfNeeded` was causing problems, I'm not sure why but sometimes (once in 3-4 screen openings) I was getting  self.topLayoutGuide.length == 0 (instead of 64) in the last `-viewDidLayoutSubviews` call and that caused wrong insets. If I call instead `setNeedsLayout` then the problem is gone. 

I tested a version without this line - looks fine so I'll remove it.

When keyboard is shown/hidden the insets are changed in `jsq_didReceiveKeyboardWillChangeFrameNotification:` method - you have an animation there that calls  `jsq_setCollectionViewInsetsTopValue:` directly. At least the demo app behaviour looks ok to me.

The main reason why I changed that line: self.inputToolbar.frame may change (and it really does) after `viewDidLayoutSubviews` call. And we never get correct insets. I didn't find any callback to catch that frame change.
Btw I'm also not very happy about this change but that's the best I was able to get.

ah, right. 👍 

so `-setBounds:` would be better than `-layoutSubviews` right?
